awd_titl_txt: Conference: Workshop: 2023 Conference on Computer Supported Cooperative Work & Social Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides funding to support about 12 promising graduate students to participate in a two-day Doctoral Research Symposium to be held on Oct 14-15, 2023 in conjunction with the ACM 2023 Conference on Computer Supported Cooperative Work & Social Computing (CSCW) in Minneapolis, MN.  CSCW is the premier international forum for research investigating the design and use of technologies that affect groups, organizations, communities, and networks.  CSCW research spans a wide range of work, civic, and everyday life activities, as well as a wide range of computing technologies and academic disciplines.  The CSCW doctoral consortia, which began in 1992, serve to bring together students and mentors across the wide range of topics, devices, institutions, and disciplines the CSCW community encompasses, providing an important place for exchange of ideas in the broader community.  These events have long helped young doctoral scholars both refine their research and advance their professional development within the CSCW community under the guidance of experienced mentors in the field.  

Goals of the doctoral consortium include building a cohort group of new researchers who will then have a network of colleagues spread out across the world, guiding the work of new researchers by having experts in the research field mentor them and provide constructive advice, and making it possible for promising new entrants to the field to attend their research conference. Students will give brief presentations about their research, followed by discussion and constructive feedback both from members of the faculty panel and other student participants. The feedback will be geared to helping students understand and articulate how their work is positioned relative to other CSCW research, whether their topics are adequately focused for thesis research projects, whether their methods are correctly chosen and applied, and whether their results are appropriately analyzed and presented.  Mentors will discuss different aspects of research the research profession, including career paths, funding, work-life balance, and related topics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The CSCW 2023 Doctoral Consortium (DC) provided opportunities for doctoral students to attend a leading ACM conference. Professors Rosa Arriaga and Susan Wyche co-organized this year’s event. The DC was held on October 15 at the Hyatt Regency Hotel, as part of the ACM 2023 Conference on Computer Supported Cooperative Work and Social Computing in Minneapolis, MN. The goal of the DC was to provide a forum for promising PhD students to present their research and receive constructive feedback. Community building was another significant goal.

We started planning the DC in January 2023, by recruiting mentors to review students’ applications and developing the call for participation (CFP). To solicit a broader pool of potential mentors, we created a lightweight application process (see Google survey). We publicized the call for mentors using social media and email listservs. 17 scholars from academia and industry applied. Applicants represented a diverse range of career levels, institutions and departments. We invited all to participate in the event. Each mentor reviewed at least three students’ applications [1]; 12 also attended the session.

In March 2023, we distributed the student call for participation via social media and email. We also contacted faculty at universities with smaller and/or newly formed CSCW-related graduate programs, and faculty at HBCUs and Hispanic Serving Institutions that have CSCW research programs.

To be considered for the workshop, PhD students submitted: a 4–6-page research overview, a CV, and a letter of support from their advisor. We received 43applicants from a broad range of disciplines that inform CSCW.  Mentors used this Google form  to prepare their reviews. They were asked to evaluate applications using these criteria: Research Motivation;  Relevance to CSCW; Presentation Clarity; Stage in PhD Program; and Community Engagement.

Mentors were given 3 weeks to complete their reviews. Each application was reviewed by 2 mentors. We relied on these reviews, and our assessments of applicants’ materials to decide who to accept/reject. Preference was given to students with a clearly defined research topic aligned with the interests of the CSCW research community. We also prioritized students who had defended their dissertations proposals, were within one-two years of graduating, and would benefit most from receiving feedback from CSCW scholars. We accepted 14/43 students (32% acceptance rate).

Prior to the DC  students, mentors and the DC co-chairs attended an ACM-funded “Welcome Dinner." Students and mentors introduced themselves at the event. The following morning  the workshop began (see schedule). We began the workshop by discussing our goals and providing students with guidance on how to give an “elevator pitch,” and to be an “active listener.”

Prior to the workshop, we grouped the students into four groups based on their research topics: Online Information Curation;Computational Journalism and Information Dissemination; Intelligent Systems; and Health and Wellness. Each group was assigned three mentors. Students gave 15-minute presentations. Mentors had five minutes to provide feedback. Towards the end of the DC, mentors answered this question, “What is something you know now, that you wish you knew as a PhD student?”

Evaluation                                                                                                                              Following the workshop as survey was sent to participants; 10 responded. Feedback was positive; students reported increasing their knowledge of CSCW topics and that they were satisfied with the workshop.

This anwer was representative of those in response to this question, “Where your expectations met for DC participation?

Yes, the expectations where met. I was surprised that none did work similar to mine, but instead I got insights into the diverse research that are conducted within CSCW.

However, students’ comments also suggested that they wanted more opportunities to interact with mentors.

Future DC organizers might consider creating more informal opportunities for students and mentors to interact. Further, we encourage organizers to use the PCS system to record mentors’ reviews rather than Google forms.

Participants

• Zhila Aghajari, Lehigh

• Marianne  Le Quéré, Cornell Tech

• Andrew Beers, Washington

• Dipto Das,  Colorado

• Melanie Duckert Schmidt, University of Copenhagen

• Conner Esterwood, Michigan

• Renkai Ma, Penn State

• Joy Ming, Cornell

• Terrance Mok, Calgary

• Lan Li, UNC

• Valerie Lookingbill, South Carolina

• Amy Rechkemmer, Purdue

• Yasaman S. Sefidgar, Washington

• Ben Zhang, Michigan

Mentors/Affiliation

  • Elena Agapie,  UC Irvine*
  • Nazanin Andalibi,  Michigan*
  • Joey Chiao-Yin Hsiao, Yahoo
  • Christina Chung, UC Santa Cruz*
  • Colin Gray, Indiana
  • Oliver Haimson, Michigan*
  • Hyunggu Jung, University of Seoul*
  • Tiffany Knearem, Google*
  • Alex Leavitt, Independent*
  • Kurt Luther, VaTech
  • Helena Mentis, UMBC*
  • Bryan Semaan, CU Boulder*
  • Shriti Raj, San Francisco State
  • Rezvaneh Rezapour, Drexel
  • Jessica Vitak, Maryland*
  • Hao-Chuan Wang, UC Davis*
  • Zhicong Lu,  Hong Kong*

Outcomes

 Students presented their research during a poster session. The extended abstracts can be found in the ACM Digital Library. We documented all workshop materials and shared them with the CSCW'24 chairs.

[1] Mentors reviewed applications with whom they do not have a conflict.

* Reviewed applications and attended

 


Last Modified: 12/21/2023
Modified by: Susan Wyche
